@banhu sahu - the exhaled gas in the balloon only differs in terms of CO2 content from inhaled air by about 5 to 6%.  In other words, he did NOT fill the balloon with CO2, or even with a high concentration of CO2.  There's plenty of oxygen remaining to support combustion of the match.  Have you never accelerated combustion of a small flame by blowing on it, for instance when making a campfire?  If your breath were just nitrogen and CO2, it would extinguish the flame.
Balloons terrify me ;—;

THE BALOON DID NOT SHRINK BECAUSE...

the same amount of carbon dioxide is produced as oxygen is used up.

why because of the equation...

C+O2~CO2
from the reaction we can see that the same amount of moles of oxygen per unit time is used up and is equal to the same amount of moles of carbon dioxide per unit time being created (look at the equation ^^^)

now... VOlUME=moles*24

if moles of oxygen used=moles of co2 created. Then when oxygen combust the same volume of oxygen which is removed is replaced with the same volume of carbon dioxide.

to conclude, the volume remains constant.

even if there is incomplete combustion occuring.

You actually only use a little of the oxygen in the air. Air we inhale is 21% oxygen. When we exhale during normal respiration there is still 14-16% oxygen left over. The oxygen in a carbon dioxide molecule is in a different oxidation state compared to the oxygen atoms found in pure oxygen molecules, O2. CO2 is therefore not a substitute for O2 in the combustion reaction. In fact, some fire extinguishers use CO2 to stop combustion.

CO2 is not an oxidizer and cannot sustain combustion because the O2 is combined with the C.  Enough of it will extinguish a flame by displacing the usable O2.  They make fire extinguishers that contain pure CO2 for this reason.

Darkvoid52 is right but there's more. The head of the match is made with about 50% of potassium chlorate which acts as oxidant for the rest of the mixture. So if you lighted this match in a baloon completely filled with co2 or helium or nitrogen... with no oxygen at all, its head would still burn, but the wood wouldn't.

In the egg experiment, the egg is forced into the bottle due to a pressure drop created when the fire in the bottle goes out, cooling the air inside.  In the case of this experiment, the match is burned, both heating the air and releasing gases, and causing it to expand.  If you watch the balloon closely when it lights, you can actually see it expand a little.  If you were to leave it in until it uses all of the oxygen, it would cool and contract a little. The air you breath in is roughly;
77% Nitrogen
21.2% Oxygen
1% Argon
.8% Trace gasses

You breath out roughly
77% Nitrogen
16-18% Oxygen (dependant on work and fitness)
4-6% Carbon Di-Oxide
1% Argon
.8% Trace gasses

Plenty of oxygen for a fire, or for a human to rebreath again!

When you breath out CO2 isn't the only thing you breathe out there is oxygen as well as other gasses from the air. Your lungs don't absorb every bit of oxygen you breath in. question: Fire needs oxygen to "survive," so how did the match ignite when all you blew in the balloon was CO2?

By opposite side, I assume you meant on the other end of the visible light spectrum (e.g. red vs. blue), then the answer to your question is yes. 
You can even shine rays that is invisible to human eye, such as x-ray or intense infrared to pop those balloons.
The key is, if the balloon absorbs the energy of the ray, it heats up and blow. On the other hand, when the ray pass through it completely or balloon reflects all of it, then it will not pop.
I got one challenge for you. I want you to try and light up as much matches as you can inside a balloon without popping it. Hope you to give some feedback. By the way , I love this channel.

Yep - this is the best chance of a pop - except black, which absorbs all colours. 
e.g. Green laser, fires green light onto a green balloon - the baloon looks green because it reflects only green light - all other frequencys are absorbed i.e. heat (not talkning about transparency which is diffrent)... so as green light is reflected little/none is absorbed as heat... so no pop....  but a red laser on a green baloon... none of the light is reflected and all is absorbed as heat... POP!

It might, but the balloon’s skin is thin is able to radiate the excess heat in both directions. that’s why it’s easier to use a solar death ray to start a fire on the solid wooden planks of a ship than on the sails. The pitch doesn’t even help, since it cools down the wood until it boils away (in a few seconds).

Mostly to do with the color here. Being it is mostly transparent. Almost none of the energy in the light is converted into heat, and so shines right through. Remember, the laser is not hot in itself, it is a high powered light. On a dark surface which can absorb this energy it will be transferred as heat. Being the match is for the most part dark it was able to absorb enough light as heat to ignite. Simple :P
That's not possible it should work like a lit match In a closed jar the fire could not start without oxygen. It's simple science

light travels in waves, and the waves from the laser will pass through the material of the balloon easily because of how porous a balloon is on an atomic level. also, the atoms that make up the balloon will need much energy to excite the electrons (this is more chemistry than physics) and the laser obviously doesnt have enough. btw, gamma rays dont mean great amounts of energy, just a high frequency.

White absorbs very little light while black absorbs a lot of light. I wouldn't quite word it as 'reflecting heat', and you're somewhat right, but even if it was black, it's transparent enough so the light just kinda goes through it instead of 'on' it.

Well, quite a few of them *are* high powered enough (They generally range from tens of milliwatts to hundreds of milliwatts in indoor shows), yet they either spread the beams out with diffraction gratings, or scan the laser so quickly over a large area that any one person gets only a very brief, non-damaging exposure. The calculations for what is safe can be quite complex however, and you're right... it's still a good idea to look away. Wikipedia has a good article on 'audience scanning'.

In an EQ RXN your formula (equation) will still be balanced AND the products will equal the limiting reactant as determined by the K value, however the RXN itself doesn't balance the equation or itself (they are unrelated) - the RXN proceeds towards equilibrium until it consumes the limiting reagent or reaches an equilibrium of K=1. 
The original statement was that the balloon didn't shrink or grow because the rxns balanced each other - which isn't accurate or correct.
i thought flame ate air why didnt the balloon shrink?
It didn't pop because it was magic!

@Zaviex The point I was making was that the reactions didn't balance itself out, which the original poster stated. Equations are balanced, not reactions (which was I think your point). Equilibrium does not mean Balanced, the EQ constant K is a Rate. A ratio of exchange at which reactants and products intro-convert. And as you stated this is a combustion RXN ... it is a one way RXN, not equilibrium as H2O & CO2 are not simultaneously reconverting to Cellulose and O2.

@Zaviex A) This isn't an equilibrium reaction, so your comment was moot. B) What is the Equilibrium Constant K for then? Mr. Smartypants.
@TheMattwasherein1992 its 3000mw of 445nm, the camera picks it up as a bit violet.

@Nexus2Eden in an EQ reaction or equilibrium reaction(you seemed to miss that as you demonstrated a combustion not an EQ) the reaction moves the ratios towards equilibrium once it starts so yes it does balance itself

@Zaviex Yes, they do. The entire point of an 'equation' is that it is balanced and equal. The reaction does not balance itself - you start with a balanced reaction: Cellulose is an organic compound with the formula (C6H10O5) ... C6H10O5 + O2 (add heat) = 5H2O + 6CO2 Which means that for every molecule of cellulose you burn in oxygen you get 5 molecules of water and 6 molecules of carbon dioxide. The EQ is balanced, it doesn't balance itself. The chemicals just react in that ratio.

@pikuorguk That isn't how chemistry works, I'm afraid. The chemical reactions don't balance out - they are balanced to begin with. And water doesn't cool things - evaporation does or any endothermic reaction as they pull energy out of the system.

@matrixrory Hydrogen would be the easiest and probably the most reactive (The Hindenburg was full of hydrogen, which is why it blew up) but any hydrocarbon would also react (methane, propane, butane, etc.) They are just hydrogen and carbon chains, once ignited rapidly break apart in O2 (oxygen) to make water (H2O) and Carbon dioxide (CO2) - its the re-creation of bonds between the hydrogen and oxygen that give off the heat and light as making a bond releases energy.

@matrixrory It wouldn't be dangerous at all Helium isn't flammable it is a Noble Gas (i,e. it doesn't react)
@matrixrory Helium is an inert gas, it doesn't burn so it would be the same as what you see on the video.

@cen0322 No, it is just a chemical reaction - combustion in any form produces water (usually vapor) and CO2 as byproducts. Only rapid energetic reactions 'explode' but even just burning a candle gives off water vapor and CO2...any 'fire' does as it converts fuel (usually a hydrocarbon) into energy = breaking chemical bonds and creating new ones. This experiment is an excellent example of of a 'closed' system. They trapped the water vapor and CO2, excellent. :)
